My first day at the
 market 
 
 Timothy Kabare and Ursula
 Nafula 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 I live in Kakuma vilage, a very hot dry 
 place, ful of thorny tres, and more 
 
 goats than people. 
 Even the market place is quiet, with only 
 a few smal shops. Most people use 
 
 bicycles for transport. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One morning my mother caled me and said, “Etabo, today
 you turn six years old. We have a present for you.”
 
 
 “What is it? What is it?” I asked eagerly. 
 
 
 “Tomorow we’re going by bus to the market in Eldoret,” she
 replied, “And we’re taking you with us!” 
 
 
 My first visit to the city! I was so excited that I could hardly
 slep that night. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The next day at the Kakuma bus stop, I 
 
 stod betwen my mother and my aunt 
 in my new pair of blue jeans and red T- 
 shirt. 
 
 
 I felt very smal betwen my tal slender 
 
 mother and my big round aunt. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The bus was very ful, so I had to sit on
 
 my mother’s lap. 
 
 Tired from the heat and excitement, I
 
 slept the whole way and saw nothing.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The sun was just rising when we reached Eldoret market. 
 
 At the entrance was a woman seling grains. Over in one 
 
 corner there were two men geting ready to lay out their 
 swet potatoes. 
 
 
 Over in another corner was a short woman holding a shiny 
 blue helicopter. 
 
 “Mother, mother, lok at that helicopter!” But mother puled 
 me away. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 In the midle of the market, there was a large stal that sold
 diferent types of fruit. 
 Some of them I had never sen before. 
 
 
 “What are the names of these fruits?” I asked my mother.
 She pointed at some: “These are oranges, and these are
 
 guavas.” 
 
 
 I turned around and said, “And these?” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Of al the fruits at the stal, I liked the 
 aples most. I liked their shape and 
 colour. I wondered how they tasted. 
 
 I turned to mother and said, “Could you 
 buy one for me?” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 As son as she gave me the aple, I let
 
 go of my mother’s hand, tok the fruit
 with both hands, and bit into the juicy
 flesh. 
 
 I had never enjoyed a fruit the way I
 enjoyed that aple. 
 
 Al I cared about was my aple. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When I finished the aple, I loked up to talk to my mother. 
 But she was not there! I loked where we had come from, 
 
 but my mother and aunt were not there. 
 
 I loked to the right, then to the left. But they were nowhere 
 
 to be sen. “Have you sen my mother?” I asked the women 
 seling potatoes nearby. They tok no notice. I started to cry. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 A while later, a woman tok me by the
 hand and led me to a place where there
 
 were other children. 
 A big man with a thick beard asked,
 “What’s your name, boy?” 
 
 “E-ta-bo,” I replied through my tears.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 I wondered if children were also sold at 
 the market. I stoped crying and loked 
 
 around to se if anyone would buy the 
 children in the rom. Son a woman 
 came in and picked up one of the 
 
 children. 
 “I wil be the next one to be taken away,” I 
 
 thought. “And then I’l never go home 
 again!” 
 I started crying once more. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When I heard the big man with the thick
 beard saying, “Where is Etabo?” I cried
 
 even harder. 
 “But I do not want to go with you!” I
 sobed. 
 
 I ran away from him. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When my mother and aunt heard my 
 
 name, they rushed to the rom. 
 “Etabo, Etabo!” a familiar voice caled. 
 It was my mother. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 As I got up to hug my mother, my aunt
 said, “Etabo, we were loking for you to
 
 give you your birthday present.”
 And from a big bag, she puled out a
 shiny blue helicopter. 
 
 “It’s yours!” she said.
